title: The Way We Are: It Started with the Greeks
description: The Ancient Greece based origins of modern Western Civilization's primary value of individuality driven curiosity that drives it to question and explore reality.

title: In the Light of the Above: Medieval Conflict - Faith and Reason
description: Introduction of the knowledge from captured Islamic Spanish libraries transforms the Europe's conception of knowledge and the fact that it can advance.

title: Point of View: Scientific Imagination in the Renaissance
description: The introduction of perspective techniques transforms Europe's use of art, architecture, geography and navigation among others with its revolutionary concept of remote positioning.

title: A Matter of Fact: Printing Transforms Knowledge
description: The introduction of practical mass printing ends Europe's predominate reliance on memory and its related concepts of reality and authority.

title: Infinitely Reasonable: Science Revises the Heavens
description: The publication of Copernicus' theory of a heliocentric universe profoundly challenged Europe's concept of the universe and the authority of the Church.

title: Credit Where It's Due: The Factory and Marketplace Revolution
description: The rise of land enclosure and advances in engineering help transform the West's major economic philosophies.

title: What the Doctor Ordered: Social Impacts of New Medical Knowledge
description: The advance of modern medicine and public health comes at the cost of the fields becoming depersonalized with their increasing use of statistics and microbiology.

title: Fit to Rule: Darwin's Revolution
description: The introduction of Charles Darwin's theory of evolution undermines the concept of divine creation while providing a rationale for both capitalism and communism.

title: Making Waves: The New Physics - Newton Revised
description: As modern theoretical physics becomes more ambiguous in nature, the Western lay public increasingly confuses advances in engineering with pure science.

title: Worlds Without End: Changing Knowledge, Changing Reality
description: James sums up his ideas about the effect of different worldviews on science by showing how different cultures approach it in their own way.
